instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hi. No liquid damage. Looks like SMC was replaced. Original the fan would spin once for 3 seconds but not recently. All power rails are present up to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>. Diode mode 0.412. Have 12.6V on 23 of <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>. <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is 3.4.V. Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>. Diode on this line is .480. Thanks for your help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> missing issue is always a pain in the ass, as usual check bios termination resistors and PCH clock

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thank you Smiba. appreciate it. Kind of unsure where to locate but will figure it out. Thanks again.

threads.message:

Hey Duke.
Not sure on the history of computer to be honest. Board looks very clean in the way of liquid damage. Only minor discoloration to the right of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> (if the SMC was on your right side) No other obvious damage jumps out at me. Im assuming SMC is legit. There was something on it that looked like flux but turned out to be nothing. Thanks, have a good one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Why is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> at 0.768V? You need to fix that first before we can get to S4 or S3

<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> high? If yes what's the resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Isnt <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> created at <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>? Same as <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>? If Im missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> then how can this be fixed. Or will the chip create <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> seperatly? Which in turn could supply <CHIP>U9550</CHIP> which then could help with my <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL> issue? Im not at work right now, but I remeber checking <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> high and I believe it was 3.42 V. Looking for datasheet on <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>. Thanks for the help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is created at <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>, but without having all the S5 power lines the chip won't even be told to generate <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>.

Without <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> being at ~3.3V the system simply won't go any further, big chances that solving this issue will also bring <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.

If <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> was high (>3V) check the resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> to see if its a (semi-)short.
If its not, fair chance that replacing <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> will solve your issues

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thank you. Im sure you are busy. I appreciate you taking the time to reply and your explanation is helpful. I will check tomorrow. You have a great night/day. :)

Diode mode <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 130V. Replaced <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and I now have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> at 3.3 V. Fan spins once around and stops. Unfortunately still do not have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.


<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> - 0.001V.


<CHIP>U2800</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If the fan spins around once it means you've hit a S0 state, but something goes wrong after that and it falls back to S5. (<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> is probably is high for a split second)

Because the system goes back to S5, <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> becomes low again. Its a signal thats only there in a S0 state
<CHIP>U7201</CHIP> is most likely not the issue anymore and is working

Does <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stays stable at 12.6V? (Check this while plugging in the charger to see if it drops while the fan spins)
Also check <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>/1/2/3 if they're high

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: OK. Will check this out in the morning. I have frequently measured G3H and Im pretty sure its around 12.56 V with the fan off. But will do like you said and double check and check those resistors. What about PM _SLP_S4_L? Shouldnt that still be present while in an S5 state? Thanks a lot man. Have a good one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: If the fans spin then <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> is coming high and all voltages are present. The only one missing could be CPU Vcore or GPU Vcore. Has the GPU been messed with?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hey Duke. It very well could have been now that you mention it.. Thermal compound doesn't look original. Some discoloration. But board is clean and edge bonding still on. Doesn't mean someone didn't hit it with a paint stripper I guess. I will look closer tomorrow. Thanks.

threads.message:
Hi. G3H is steady at 12.56 V.

<RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR> - 3.337 V
<RESISTOR>R1803</RESISTOR> - 3.337 V

Thanks.

Duke. You mentioned GPU Vcore. Doesnt it need <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> to function?  Which I am missing.

Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The fans are spinning right? That means all power is fine. If GPU is shorted the board will shut down when GPU Vcore is turned on.

threads.message: Ohhhh. I seeee. :o lol.  Thanks Smiba for all your help and info very appreciative. Duke... Till next time.
